content.description: One of the best routes on the wall. It starts with fingers, moves to hands, then to an off-width fist/stack as it reaches the cruxy roof. Once you pass the roof there's a second crux with an awkward mantle, then smooth sailing. Watch for the massive loose block making up the right side of the crack just below the roof.
content.protection: Standard rack to #6 camalot. No anchors, but plenty of trees to sling at the top.
content.location: This is the large, right leaning crack halfway down the wall.

content.description: A bouldery start to reachy crimps with technical footwork. The crux is 3/4 of the way up with some small crimps and slopers just below the tree. It's cruiser after you hit the big blocks by the small tree!
content.protection: Doesn't take gear, but can be TRd. Just sling a tree at the top.
content.location: Just to the right of Elbows Deep, and straight up the face. Stay out of the crack, and don't wander right to the big ledges.

content.description:
Head up the slab with underclings, side pulls, and crimps. Lower section is the crux. When you hit the ramp it eases off to a 5.4. Follow the ramp up and left around the bush, to top out above Big Crimpin'. 

  An alternative start (5.6 variation)heads up the Elbows Deep crack until you hit the roof, then traverses right to the ramp with the bush.
content.protection: TR only. Can be done from the same tree as Big Crimpin'.
content.location: Start at the two small overhangs immediately to the right of Big Crimpin'.

content.description:
This is the first major wall you'll come to while hiking in from Shenandoah. It's a west facing cliff ~80ft high at the base of the overlook for the upper falls. Be warned: the northern section of the wall (closest to the falls,) is at the base of a prominent overlook, so tourons may occasionally drop rocks or other debris from above. Your anchor may also be accessible to hikers. The further south (downstream,) you go along the wall, the less accessible the top is to hikers. 

  Really high quality rock for the most part, though there are several large blocks that should be trundled. All trad or TR, and easy to set anchors on the trees at the top of the wall.
